intro: Draba lemmonii, commonly known as Lemmon's whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly habitats, often in alpine or subalpine regions. It has basal leaves that are lance-shaped and hairy, and it produces clusters of white or pale yellow flowers in early spring. Draba lemmonii is an herbaceous perennial that plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native environments.
